Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Polyelectrolyte Devices Based on Ion Current
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY

A family of circuit components made from charged polymers and relying on ion current, instead of electron current, is proposed. Key materials will be based on polyelectrolyte complexes, prepared by mixing oppositely charged polymers, which form a rugged phase of amorphous, soft matter. This project involves both synthesis and characterization of polymers and polymer nanocomposites. The following components are to be made in this new paradigm: resistor, capacitor, transistor, memory. Each of these components relies on creative control of ion permeability through ultrathin films of these polyelectrolyte complexes. The resistors are designed to be controlled by an external potential. Capacitors rely on electrochemical storage or release of charge. Memory events will be created by quasipermanent modification of ion permeability. Transistors are designed to be directly "gated" by biomacromolecules in solution. In a closely coupled small angle neutron scattering study (SANS), the conformation of polymer components that make up the complex will be determined, using deuterated polyelectrolytes and contrast matching of the background.


NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY

Circuits that use current of ions instead of electrons will be developed using charged polymers. Just as a lump of amorphous silicon can be transformed into an electronic circuit of the type on which our civilization is based, so too can a blob of amorphous charged polymer be shaped into useful devices. These ion current devices will reproduce the behavior of familiar circuit elements, such as the resistor, diode, capacitor, transistor and memory. The significance of using ion-based devices is that they are more easily integrated with natural systems, such as cells, which rely exclusively on ion currents. Thus, the proposed research will help us to interface the living world to the electronic environment. The project will exploit the unique ability of some polymers, many of which are used widely in society for other purposes, to conduct ion charge at room temperature. During the course of the work, undergraduate and graduate students will be required to think and operate beyond the usual definitions and materials for electronic circuits. They will also use state-of-the art facilities at Oak Ridge National Laboratory to study their novel materials. Built into the project is a research opportunity for an underrepresented minority student from Albany State University.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Polyelectrolytes are ubiquitous charged polymers which are usually water soluble. Polyelectrolyte complexes, PECs, are amorphous blends of oppositely-charged polyelectrolytes held together by multiple ion pairings between positive and negative units. PECs may be processed into thin films using the alternating or “multilayer” technique. Ions are critical components in PECs. Ions control physical properties such as modulus and permeability. This EAGER grant explored the properties of PECs which would be needed to make devices from them.

    Our first discovery was that the polymer chains in PECs are tightly coiled, which means the repulsive interactions between like charges on the same chain have been largely neutralized. Since the polyelectrolytes are well blended and amorphous, devices made from them will not suffer from grain boundaries.

    Next, we measured the temperature dependence of ion transport through PECs. The response of devices relying on ion current depends on how fast the ions move through the PEC. We found that ion transport, characterized by the diffusion coefficient in the PEC, was strongly activated by temperature.

     In a breakthrough in processing, we discovered that adding salt to PECs plasticized them enough to be extruded through a standard laboratory extruder. Extrusion, a widely-used industrial technique, provides large quantities of material in the shape of rods, films, tubes and any cross-section. Such “saloplastic” behavior means that polyelectrolytes can now be considered more broadly as engineering materials rather than just as coatings or solution modifiers.

   We synthesized a novel polyelectrolyte containing redox active units which demonstrated the concept of reversible crosslink formation in PECs under redox control. When one of these redox active units is reduced (the addition of an electron) an internal ion pair crosslink is broken and more ions enter the  PEC, which makes the material softer. We demonstrated the intriguing concept that the modulus of a material could be reversibly changed by about an factor of ten using only an electrochemical “switch.”

 

    In addition to the broader impacts of demonstrating large-scale processibilty of a material once labeled “unprocessible,” we extended the technology internationally via a collaboration with the University of Strasbourg and CNRS in France. Together, we demonstrated a microporous PEC material with potential for use in drug delivery devices. We showed that enzymes immobilized in the porous PEC lost none of their activity and could be reused/recycled. The technology and applications of PECs was exploited in teaching undergraduate and graduate students about polymer science. Three graduate students and one postdoctoral associate supported by the project have started full-time careers in academics or industry.
